April 18, 1901.
LACROSSE.

J. H. U., 4.
U. OF P., 1.
Black and Blue opened her inter-colHE
legiate lacrosse season on last Saturday
afternoon when she defeated the University of
Pennsylvania team at the new athletic grounds
on the York Road by a score of 4 to 1. This
is the second consecutive time that the wearers
of the Red and Blue have suffered defeat at
the hands of our team, and by so doing have
very auspiciously opened the present season.
The result of the game showed much to both
sides. Pennsylvania succeeded in scoring a
goal and in holding down her opponents to a
small score. While our boys showed that
they had in there numbers men who will
become worthy successors to Maddren, McInness, Foster, Grimes, Guggenheimer, and
others whose names are still dear to every
loyal Hopkins man. To be sure the men were
still raw owing to the number of new men,
but even in the little time which had elapsed
since the All-Baltimore game, a decided improvement could be noticed. The University
of Pennsylvania team showed a decided improvement over last year's form, notwithstanding the loss of such men as Cross, Thomas,
and Van Valkenberg. Brommell, ex-captain
of the Swarthmore team, and Orton, Pennsy's
famous miler, have been acting as coaches,
and the result of their work was quite apparent
especially in their team work.
When .the game was called a fair crowd
occupied the grandstand and yelled encouragement to their favorites. In the first
half the ball hovered for some minutes dangerously near the Hopkins goal, but soon "Aber"

T

No. 13

secured it and hurried it up the field to the
attack. Clever work by Hatch and Palmer
Bernheim soon advanced it to the elder Bernheim who missed the play, and Penn. again got
the ball, but soon it was back again in Pennsie's territory and Putts made an attempt for
a goal, but failed. After two more failures
Bernheim was able to put it in the net, and
made the first point for Hopkins. When the
ball was again in play it was secured by
Ebaugh, who shot high for a try at goal.
Ranft only partially stopped it and the ball
rolled into the net just before the referee's
whistle sounded for the end of the first half.
In the second half our boys took a big brace,
and three goals by Putts were the result before
the half was over. Putts is a new man and
will find it hard work to fill his position as his
predecessor, McInness, did, but on Saturday,
steadied by the older men on the attack, Bernheim and Bandel, he displayed considerable
ability in the way he covered his territory.
Hatch and Bernheim, also new men on the
attack, showed splendid form and a thorough
knowledge of the game. Ranft, the new goal
keeper, still lacks experience, but was unusually good for a new tender. He turned aside
several"hot" shots, but was unfortunate in
having one drop from his stick and roll into
the net after he had partially stopped it.
"Bill" Schmeiser, one of the old men, played in his usual way. He alone cut off several
excellent shots that were going straight for
the goal by simply jumping in the way, and
was able to surprise the newer men by his
coolness. Tyler at cover point captained his
team and took everything that came his way.
Bruton played in the same old energetic way

and the two freshmen, Tough and Earnest
Schmeiser, did most creditable work on the
defense. Abercrombie was always at the
right place at the right time, and caused much
merriment for the spectators in the way he
dodged his opponent.
As a team the defense put up much the
stronger game, but the attack did well and no
doubt will improve when they have played together longer.

BASE BALL.
more an attempt is being made among,
ONCE
the students of the University to organize a
first class base ball team, and for several reasons the .enterprise promises to terminate successfully. Captain "Pete" Moore and Manager
Frank Neer are giving their undivided attention to the necessary arrangements, and thus
far the encouragingly large squad of candidates

3

has been very prompt in showing up for
practice.
The revival of interest in the national sport
at Hopkins has been due in a large measure to
the efforts of Manager Neer. For several
weeks past he has endeavered to inform himself with regard to the material at the University and the spirit of those interested in the
sport. The investigation ended in having a
meeting, on April 5, of the old players, at which
it was decided that an attempt should be made
to start the movement. Accordingly, practice
was held on the following day at American
League Park; it resulted favorably, and upon
several occasions during the past week over a
dozen candidates have turned out. Among
the men who intend to try for positions are
Carr, formerly second-baseman on the University of North Carolina; Baker, who used to
pitch for Western Maryland College; Neer, of
the Rock Hill College team; "Pete" Moore,
Atkinson, Humphreys, Campbell, Constantine,
Blanck, E Strouse, Hand, Naigel, Moorse,
Adelsdorf, Duck, Lupton, Marine, Boyer,
Gutman, Yearley, Frazier, Stubbs, and Smith,
of the Medical School. This list should
certainly prove encouraging to the promoters
of the project. Among the number are almost
all the old players, and several new ones who
have made very favorable impressions on Captain Moore. Coaching by such men as McGraw
and Robinson will be of great benefit to
the candidates. President Reese of the Athletic Association and Physical Director Mackdemott have promised to aid the movement in
every way possible. Encouraged by the success attained, therefore, Manager Neer has
opened communication with a number of
colleges. Among them are Lehigh, Georgetown, Rutgers, Gallaudet, and Rock Hill. He
also hopes to enter a Hopkins' nine in the
Inter-Collegiate League against St. John's and
Western Maryland. Who knows but what
another pennant may be hung to the trophy
room before the football season. Let us hope
so; but at the same time, let every man who
knows what a baseball is come out and try for
a position. This is the only way to organize
a winning team•

there has been much speculation and
OF late
no little newspaper talk regarding the progress being made in raising the million dollar
endowment fund. One of the papers circulated
the report that the entire sum had been raised,
which statement brought forth a strong denial
on the part of the Trustees of the University.
As a matter of fact the million has by no
means been raised; as yet only about half having been subscribed. As soon as the total
amount is reached the announcement will be
made, and until then there is nothing to do
but patiently wait.

w

striking example of "truth crushed to
earth" has been afforded the scholastic
world by the summary dismissal of two of
Leland Stanford University's most brilliant
professors, because in a free country, enjoying
the rights of free press and free speech, these
gentlemen dared to express their opinions regarding certain economic questions of vital
importance.
When Dr. Ross, professor in economics,
pointed out the pernicious influence of under-

A

paid Chinese labor being brought into competition with American workmen, he was informed that his services at Leland Stanford could
be dispensed with, for she who controlled the
University finances employs Chinese labor.
A few weeks later, Dr. Howard, in tracing
the causes leading up to the French Revolution, discovered some startling comparisons
between the methods of the degenerate French
aristocracy and those employed by American
capitalists and capitalistic corporations. He
emphasized the necessity of public ownership
of natural monopolies, and declared himself
positively in favor of municipal ownership of
street railways, etc. He showed that little
difference existed between the "fiade defamine"
or famous grain ring of Louis XV, and similar combinations of the present time. In conclusion he said, "I have a negative as well as
a positive creed. I do not worship Saint Market Street; I do not reverence holy Standard
Oil, nor do I doff my cap to the Celestial Six
Companies."
These utterances caused some consternation
in the city of the "Golden Gate." A delegation of injured capitalists representing the
interests of the Market Street Railway Co.
sought an audience with Mrs. Stanford. A
council of war was held, and it was decided
that such expressions were seditious, and, if
not curbed, would exert an unholy influence
upon the youth of the land, thereby causing it
to form profane ideas regarding the sacred character of our holy American corporations. Dr.
Howard was summoned before the high tribunal, and told to recant or go into exile, while
at the same time the fate of Dr. Ross was pictured to him in startling colors. Dr. Howard
replied that the duty of the scholar was to investigate scientifically, and speak the truth
boldly, as the guarantee of American Democracy lay in the intrepid scholar. This heretical
doctrine sealed his fate, and he was forthwith
dismissed. In Germany, the home of higher
criticism, and advanced economic thought, even
though the Universities are supported by the
government, restrictions upon free thought are
not imposed. In America the case is somewhat different, and, as a consequence many of

(In this column the NEWS-LETTER will answer, to the best of
its ability, the queries forwarded by correspondents.)

Mr. Editor: I recently had a discussion
with a literary friend in regard to the place in
the works of Julius Shakspeare where the following quotation occurs: "Beware! the Ides
do march !" My friend persisted that Omlet
said this to MacDuffy in the third inning of
Twelve Nights of Midsummer Madness, but I
am sure it was published in the Baltimore Sun
during the last presidential campaign. Can
you set us right?—Critic.
The settlement of the point under discussion requires a thorough knowledge of Textual or Lower criticism, and the editors feel
particularly fitted just now to decide, having
just passed through a course of English Literature. In the first place, the words "the
ides do march" are entirely incorrect, and
were never written by Brutus, as has been
proven by an energetic Junior of the Shakspeare class. It was discovered last month
during Exams, that the sentence should have
read "the ideas do march," according to which
Willie intended to convey the meaning that
sometimes during Exams, ideas do pass quickly
through the brain of the lad sitting in torture
and watching the minute hand of the clock
move, with all the bravery of a Cxsar. We
thought we were familiar with Shakspeare's
Divine Novels, but a thorough perusal of the
new annotated edition of the Diamond Dick
Library fails to reveal the character referred
to. Under the new interpretation the question regarding our most worthy contemporary
the Sun answers itself.
Mr. Editor: As a stranger to this city, I
should like to know whether the new Court
House or the City College is the most magnificent building in Baltimore. Would you
kindly give a short description of each?
—New York.
There can be absolutely no comparison
between the two buildings mentioned. The
Court House is built for occupancy by greyheaded upholders of the law. We are sorry
to state that we know very little of the City
College, but are under the impression that its

7

chief characteristic and greatest claim to fame
lies in the fact that it is situated next to a
great educational center.
Mr. Editor: Can you give me in one word
the main element of Spenser's poetry?
—English Student.

ATHLETIC NOTES.
Byrne has received a telegram
MANAGER
from Manager Metcalf of the Harvard
Lacrosse Team stating that they will play the
Hopkins Team in Baltimore on May the sixth
instead of the second as formerly announced.
This is the only change which has been made
in the schedule as announced in the NEwsLETTER several weeks ago.
w w
Director Mackdermott, Captain Hoffmann
and Manager Pearre have about decided on the
following entries for the Princeton handicap
games which take place on April the 20.
Robert Garrett—shot—put running high
jumps, and rnnning broad jumps. England,
440 yard run; Hoffman, 220 yard dash and
440 yard run.
Besides entering a relay team at the great
relay meet at the University of Pennsylvania
on April the 27th, it has been determined to
enter Robert Garret in the weights. Garrett
should be able to do something, for at his best
he can easily do much more than forty feet.
sr ilf W

Owing to strained legs Straus and Briscoe
have been unable to work with the Lacrosse
team for the past week, but they are gradually
improving, and soon hope to be in the game.
The Pennsylvania Lacrosse team was received by President Gilman in the Trustees
room last Saturday where he explained to them
how the University was founded and then
accorded to them the unusual honor of con.
ducting them through the McCoy Hall and
in showing them the objects of interest there.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
COMPARISONS ARE ODIOUS.

(The following are two letters written by a Freshman after
his Easter Exams.]
[I.]

DEAR MAMMA,—I take my pen in hand to
let you know that I am well and hope you are
the same. The examinations are over, and
after working very hard I succeeded in passing
all of them, and making a very good impression
upon the professors, especially Dr. Green, the
professor in Rhetoric. I have lost my report
but will send it to you as soon as I can find it.
I stayed in town because our vacation was very
short, and was invited to a friend's to spend
Easter with him. My expenses are pretty
heavy as I have joined Y. M. C. A. and a
Missionary Society started by one of our professors in history, so I have very little money
and would like to have some. Yes—I go to
church regular.
Your loving son,

CHARLES.
P. S.—I need a suit of clothes. I will send
you an account of all my expenses in my next
letter.

[2.]
DEAR FRED,—I tell you college life is great
only it's expensive. The night before examinations I went out with some fellows and
spoiled a suit of clothes, and it takes all my
knowledge of arithmetic to make up an
expense account once a month. "Figures
never lie." The profs. down here don't give
fair examinations, and I think they show
partiality, because they flunked me in every
subject except drawing and public speaking,
and I had to stay in town during vacation and
take two exams, over again. When you
flunk here they won't let you play on athletic
teams or go on musical club trips, and if it
wasn't for that I think I could do good work
on both. If you get through school this year
you better come to Hopkins next year; its lots
of fun down here. If I get a check from the
folks tomorrow I'm going out and have some
fun tomorrow night, hut I'm broke now and
I've borrowed six dollars and twenty-five cents
Yours,
from my room-mate.

CHARLIE.

P. S.—When my report came in I burnt it
up, and when the folks home wrote for it I had
to tell them I'd lost it but had passed very well.

Don't emulate the Czar.
But put away your pedigree,
And be as plain as you can be,
Because the chances are
That if your blood is very blue,
You'll have it spilt before you're through.

A life couleur de rose,—

With hot old times and pleasure rife,
Then here's what I propose:
The safest thing to do is, Teach:
Lord know's you're then past danger's reach.
VI
For example, suppose you're instructing a class
In History, Law, or Debate,
'Twill surprise how soon all your hearers pill pass
To a sort of a comatose state.

DANGER.

[The present rush of engagements of Hopkins men has caused
the News-Letter to form a new department managed by the
"Matrimonial Editor." He wishes to make his debut in this
issue with a few words of philosophic thought.]

Johns Hopkins University must be in
THE
the path of epidemic—bearing winds these
days. First a number of Freshmen were fascinated by the charms of infantile measles, now
it appears that an epidemic of that horrible
disease, that desire to bind oneself to somebody
else which is so killing, has struck the place
with a full blast. Not satisfied with carrying
away our chief rooter, and striking dismay into
the halls of W. C. B. and G. L. S. it has
caught in its whirl a member of the Junk);
Class who announces that he is going to marry.
Just let your thoughts rest for a moment on
that awe-inspiring announcement,—a Junior
going to marry. The first idea that struck
our minds was children must not play with
fire. We can easily conceive how the elderly,
serious seniors (e. g. the chief rooter) whose
thoughts are always elevated towards higher,
nobler fields where they can roam about enjoying nectarine happiness, are willing to drop all
earthly cares for the heavenly bliss of domesticity; but how Juniors, sordid, animal creatures, can possibly attain to such heights is
entirely beyond our comprehension. The
senior at 2 years of age is perfectly prepared
to turn from the heavy duties of college
routine and its noon-day lunches to a lighter,
more airy sphere; a senior can do this, but we
serionsly fear that a grave danger confronts all
Juniors who attempt such a thing.
Some means must be taken to stop the danger,—a stringent barrier placed before the
dangerous monster that to be loved needs but
to be seen, or some law proposed that will
succeed in attaining the object. We are aware
that there is a law against a minor procuring
a marriage license; there is, however, also a
law to procure one. The latter law we believe,
came into existence in 188o ; it threatens to go
out now. Most Juniors, we venture to say, are
not of age, and are therefore subject to prohibitory laws against matrimony. It is doubtful to our mind if a minor can be married with

THE NEWS-LETTER.

10

the law on his side; yes, the question is can he?
It all events we simply wish to point out
the dangers of such occurrences, it is not our
duty to stop them. We heartily congratulate
the second gentleman on the list, and desire to
state that the "matrimonial editor" is at the
service of any aspiring suitor: Freshies, your
turn next.

JUST ONE GIRL.
time was in the fall of i 900, on ThanksTHE
giving Day afternoon.
The scene was a crowded street car, carrying
a load of passengers to Union Park to see a
foot-ball game.
The chief actors were a college youth whose
first name was Sidney, and a man who had no
small change.
The conductor is going his merry rounds,
with a volley of "move up front," interspered
with "Fares please."
The tragic moment draws on apace.
The conductor approaches the aforesaid
changeless man.
The man draws a tenner, and says that is the
smallest he has.
A kid yells for a transfer; a stout lady demands that the car be stopped at once; a bald
gentleman falls over a hamper of newly washed
clothes in the care of an old negress.
The conductor glares wildly around, and
when his frenzied glance falls on the x note,
he gives a war-hoop.
It is the straw-hat that shatters the vertebral
column of the proverbial camel.
But see, a fair knight conies to the rescue!
Like Sir Philip Sidney of old, who threw a
cup of water in a dying soldier's eye, this his
modern namesake is all courtesy and grace.
He approches the changeless man.
The latter prudently put away his tenner.
But that is not the purpose of Sidney on
this occasion.
With southern polish, Sid draws a nickel
from his very own trouser's pocket, and relieves the stranger's difficulty.
At once the latter is all gratitude and
indebtedness.
"What is your name, fair sir, that I may
requite you this most opportune loan in a very
short qnickness ?"
"Oh! don't mention it. I always like to
give away a small coin in this manner. It is
only an eccentricity; think of it no more."
"Nay, but you will do me yet greater
courtesy and kindness, if you will but let me
know who has been my benefactor."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
"Truly, sir, I wish no thanks for this simple
deed."
"But let me only know your name, that in
days to come I may ponder, over it as a
synonym for all that distinguishes the gentleman; that it may stand out in my memory as
apart from all other names; that I may transmit it to my descendants as a word forever to
be held in all honor and reverence. For these
reasons, fair youth, impart to me the family
title by which you are known."
"Sir, my name is
Smith."
Stranger croaks.

April 18, 1901.
LACROSSE.

J. H. U., 4.
U. OF P., 1.
Black and Blue opened her inter-colHE
legiate lacrosse season on last Saturday
afternoon when she defeated the University of
Pennsylvania team at the new athletic grounds
on the York Road by a score of 4 to 1. This
is the second consecutive time that the wearers
of the Red and Blue have suffered defeat at
the hands of our team, and by so doing have
very auspiciously opened the present season.
The result of the game showed much to both
sides. Pennsylvania succeeded in scoring a
goal and in holding down her opponents to a
small score. While our boys showed that
they had in there numbers men who will
become worthy successors to Maddren, McInness, Foster, Grimes, Guggenheimer, and
others whose names are still dear to every
loyal Hopkins man. To be sure the men were
still raw owing to the number of new men,
but even in the little time which had elapsed
since the All-Baltimore game, a decided improvement could be noticed. The University
of Pennsylvania team showed a decided improvement over last year's form, notwithstanding the loss of such men as Cross, Thomas,
and Van Valkenberg. Brommell, ex-captain
of the Swarthmore team, and Orton, Pennsy's
famous miler, have been acting as coaches,
and the result of their work was quite apparent
especially in their team work.
When .the game was called a fair crowd
occupied the grandstand and yelled encouragement to their favorites. In the first
half the ball hovered for some minutes dangerously near the Hopkins goal, but soon "Aber"

T

No. 13

secured it and hurried it up the field to the
attack. Clever work by Hatch and Palmer
Bernheim soon advanced it to the elder Bernheim who missed the play, and Penn. again got
the ball, but soon it was back again in Pennsie's territory and Putts made an attempt for
a goal, but failed. After two more failures
Bernheim was able to put it in the net, and
made the first point for Hopkins. When the
ball was again in play it was secured by
Ebaugh, who shot high for a try at goal.
Ranft only partially stopped it and the ball
rolled into the net just before the referee's
whistle sounded for the end of the first half.
In the second half our boys took a big brace,
and three goals by Putts were the result before
the half was over. Putts is a new man and
will find it hard work to fill his position as his
predecessor, McInness, did, but on Saturday,
steadied by the older men on the attack, Bernheim and Bandel, he displayed considerable
ability in the way he covered his territory.
Hatch and Bernheim, also new men on the
attack, showed splendid form and a thorough
knowledge of the game. Ranft, the new goal
keeper, still lacks experience, but was unusually good for a new tender. He turned aside
several"hot" shots, but was unfortunate in
having one drop from his stick and roll into
the net after he had partially stopped it.
"Bill" Schmeiser, one of the old men, played in his usual way. He alone cut off several
excellent shots that were going straight for
the goal by simply jumping in the way, and
was able to surprise the newer men by his
coolness. Tyler at cover point captained his
team and took everything that came his way.
Bruton played in the same old energetic way

dodged his opponent.
As a team the defense put up much the
stronger game, but the attack did well and no
doubt will improve when they have played together longer.

BASE BALL.
more an attempt is being made among,
ONCE
the students of the University to organize a
first class base ball team, and for several reasons the .enterprise promises to terminate successfully. Captain "Pete" Moore and Manager
Frank Neer are giving their undivided attention to the necessary arrangements, and thus
far the encouragingly large squad of candidates

3

has been very prompt in showing up for
practice.
The revival of interest in the national sport
at Hopkins has been due in a large measure to
the efforts of Manager Neer. For several
weeks past he has endeavered to inform himself with regard to the material at the University and the spirit of those interested in the
sport. The investigation ended in having a
meeting, on April 5, of the old players, at which
it was decided that an attempt should be made
to start the movement. Accordingly, practice
was held on the following day at American
League Park; it resulted favorably, and upon
several occasions during the past week over a
dozen candidates have turned out. Among
the men who intend to try for positions are
Carr, formerly second-baseman on the University of North Carolina; Baker, who used to
pitch for Western Maryland College; Neer, of
the Rock Hill College team; "Pete" Moore,
Atkinson, Humphreys, Campbell, Constantine,
Blanck, E Strouse, Hand, Naigel, Moorse,
Adelsdorf, Duck, Lupton, Marine, Boyer,
Gutman, Yearley, Frazier, Stubbs, and Smith,
of the Medical School. This list should
certainly prove encouraging to the promoters
of the project. Among the number are almost
all the old players, and several new ones who
have made very favorable impressions on Captain Moore. Coaching by such men as McGraw
and Robinson will be of great benefit to
the candidates. President Reese of the Athletic Association and Physical Director Mackdemott have promised to aid the movement in
every way possible. Encouraged by the success attained, therefore, Manager Neer has
opened communication with a number of
colleges. Among them are Lehigh, Georgetown, Rutgers, Gallaudet, and Rock Hill. He
also hopes to enter a Hopkins' nine in the
Inter-Collegiate League against St. John's and
Western Maryland. Who knows but what
another pennant may be hung to the trophy
room before the football season. Let us hope
so; but at the same time, let every man who
knows what a baseball is come out and try for
a position. This is the only way to organize
a winning team•

there has been much speculation and
OF late
no little newspaper talk regarding the progress being made in raising the million dollar
endowment fund. One of the papers circulated
the report that the entire sum had been raised,
which statement brought forth a strong denial
on the part of the Trustees of the University.
As a matter of fact the million has by no
means been raised; as yet only about half having been subscribed. As soon as the total
amount is reached the announcement will be
made, and until then there is nothing to do
but patiently wait.

w

striking example of "truth crushed to
earth" has been afforded the scholastic
world by the summary dismissal of two of
Leland Stanford University's most brilliant
professors, because in a free country, enjoying
the rights of free press and free speech, these
gentlemen dared to express their opinions regarding certain economic questions of vital
importance.
When Dr. Ross, professor in economics,
pointed out the pernicious influence of under-

A

paid Chinese labor being brought into competition with American workmen, he was informed that his services at Leland Stanford could
be dispensed with, for she who controlled the
University finances employs Chinese labor.
A few weeks later, Dr. Howard, in tracing
the causes leading up to the French Revolution, discovered some startling comparisons
between the methods of the degenerate French
aristocracy and those employed by American
capitalists and capitalistic corporations. He
emphasized the necessity of public ownership
of natural monopolies, and declared himself
positively in favor of municipal ownership of
street railways, etc. He showed that little
difference existed between the "fiade defamine"
or famous grain ring of Louis XV, and similar combinations of the present time. In conclusion he said, "I have a negative as well as
a positive creed. I do not worship Saint Market Street; I do not reverence holy Standard
Oil, nor do I doff my cap to the Celestial Six
Companies."
These utterances caused some consternation
in the city of the "Golden Gate." A delegation of injured capitalists representing the
interests of the Market Street Railway Co.
sought an audience with Mrs. Stanford. A
council of war was held, and it was decided
that such expressions were seditious, and, if
not curbed, would exert an unholy influence
upon the youth of the land, thereby causing it
to form profane ideas regarding the sacred character of our holy American corporations. Dr.
Howard was summoned before the high tribunal, and told to recant or go into exile, while
at the same time the fate of Dr. Ross was pictured to him in startling colors. Dr. Howard
replied that the duty of the scholar was to investigate scientifically, and speak the truth
boldly, as the guarantee of American Democracy lay in the intrepid scholar. This heretical
doctrine sealed his fate, and he was forthwith
dismissed. In Germany, the home of higher
criticism, and advanced economic thought, even
though the Universities are supported by the
government, restrictions upon free thought are
not imposed. In America the case is somewhat different, and, as a consequence many of

THE NEWS-LETTER.
INQUIRY COLUMN.
(In this column the NEWS-LETTER will answer, to the best of
its ability, the queries forwarded by correspondents.)

Mr. Editor: I recently had a discussion
with a literary friend in regard to the place in
the works of Julius Shakspeare where the following quotation occurs: "Beware! the Ides
do march !" My friend persisted that Omlet
said this to MacDuffy in the third inning of
Twelve Nights of Midsummer Madness, but I
am sure it was published in the Baltimore Sun
during the last presidential campaign. Can
you set us right?—Critic.
The settlement of the point under discussion requires a thorough knowledge of Textual or Lower criticism, and the editors feel
particularly fitted just now to decide, having
just passed through a course of English Literature. In the first place, the words "the
ides do march" are entirely incorrect, and
were never written by Brutus, as has been
proven by an energetic Junior of the Shakspeare class. It was discovered last month
during Exams, that the sentence should have
read "the ideas do march," according to which
Willie intended to convey the meaning that
sometimes during Exams, ideas do pass quickly
through the brain of the lad sitting in torture
and watching the minute hand of the clock
move, with all the bravery of a Cxsar. We
thought we were familiar with Shakspeare's
Divine Novels, but a thorough perusal of the
new annotated edition of the Diamond Dick
Library fails to reveal the character referred
to. Under the new interpretation the question regarding our most worthy contemporary
the Sun answers itself.
Mr. Editor: As a stranger to this city, I
should like to know whether the new Court
House or the City College is the most magnificent building in Baltimore. Would you
kindly give a short description of each?
—New York.
There can be absolutely no comparison
between the two buildings mentioned. The
Court House is built for occupancy by greyheaded upholders of the law. We are sorry
to state that we know very little of the City
College, but are under the impression that its

7

chief characteristic and greatest claim to fame
lies in the fact that it is situated next to a
great educational center.
Mr. Editor: Can you give me in one word
the main element of Spenser's poetry?
—English Student.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
COMPARISONS ARE ODIOUS.

(The following are two letters written by a Freshman after
his Easter Exams.]
[I.]

DEAR MAMMA,—I take my pen in hand to
let you know that I am well and hope you are
the same. The examinations are over, and
after working very hard I succeeded in passing
all of them, and making a very good impression
upon the professors, especially Dr. Green, the
professor in Rhetoric. I have lost my report
but will send it to you as soon as I can find it.
I stayed in town because our vacation was very
short, and was invited to a friend's to spend
Easter with him. My expenses are pretty
heavy as I have joined Y. M. C. A. and a
Missionary Society started by one of our professors in history, so I have very little money
and would like to have some. Yes—I go to
church regular.
Your loving son,

CHARLES.
P. S.—I need a suit of clothes. I will send
you an account of all my expenses in my next
letter.

[2.]
DEAR FRED,—I tell you college life is great
only it's expensive. The night before examinations I went out with some fellows and
spoiled a suit of clothes, and it takes all my
knowledge of arithmetic to make up an
expense account once a month. "Figures
never lie." The profs. down here don't give
fair examinations, and I think they show
partiality, because they flunked me in every
subject except drawing and public speaking,
and I had to stay in town during vacation and
take two exams, over again. When you
flunk here they won't let you play on athletic
teams or go on musical club trips, and if it
wasn't for that I think I could do good work
on both. If you get through school this year
you better come to Hopkins next year; its lots
of fun down here. If I get a check from the
folks tomorrow I'm going out and have some
fun tomorrow night, hut I'm broke now and
I've borrowed six dollars and twenty-five cents
Yours,
from my room-mate.

CHARLIE.

P. S.—When my report came in I burnt it
up, and when the folks home wrote for it I had
to tell them I'd lost it but had passed very well.

Lord know's you're then past danger's reach.

DANGER.

[The present rush of engagements of Hopkins men has caused
the News-Letter to form a new department managed by the
"Matrimonial Editor." He wishes to make his debut in this
issue with a few words of philosophic thought.]

Johns Hopkins University must be in
THE
the path of epidemic—bearing winds these
days. First a number of Freshmen were fascinated by the charms of infantile measles, now
it appears that an epidemic of that horrible
disease, that desire to bind oneself to somebody
else which is so killing, has struck the place
with a full blast. Not satisfied with carrying
away our chief rooter, and striking dismay into
the halls of W. C. B. and G. L. S. it has
caught in its whirl a member of the Junk);
Class who announces that he is going to marry.
Just let your thoughts rest for a moment on
that awe-inspiring announcement,—a Junior
going to marry. The first idea that struck
our minds was children must not play with
fire. We can easily conceive how the elderly,
serious seniors (e. g. the chief rooter) whose
thoughts are always elevated towards higher,
nobler fields where they can roam about enjoying nectarine happiness, are willing to drop all
earthly cares for the heavenly bliss of domesticity; but how Juniors, sordid, animal creatures, can possibly attain to such heights is
entirely beyond our comprehension. The
senior at 2 years of age is perfectly prepared
to turn from the heavy duties of college
routine and its noon-day lunches to a lighter,
more airy sphere; a senior can do this, but we
serionsly fear that a grave danger confronts all
Juniors who attempt such a thing.
Some means must be taken to stop the danger,—a stringent barrier placed before the
dangerous monster that to be loved needs but
to be seen, or some law proposed that will
succeed in attaining the object. We are aware
that there is a law against a minor procuring
a marriage license; there is, however, also a
law to procure one. The latter law we believe,
came into existence in 188o ; it threatens to go
out now. Most Juniors, we venture to say, are
not of age, and are therefore subject to prohibitory laws against matrimony. It is doubtful to our mind if a minor can be married with

THE NEWS-LETTER.

10

the law on his side; yes, the question is can he?
It all events we simply wish to point out
the dangers of such occurrences, it is not our
duty to stop them. We heartily congratulate
the second gentleman on the list, and desire to
state that the "matrimonial editor" is at the
service of any aspiring suitor: Freshies, your
turn next.

JUST ONE GIRL.
time was in the fall of i 900, on ThanksTHE
giving Day afternoon.
The scene was a crowded street car, carrying
a load of passengers to Union Park to see a
foot-ball game.
The chief actors were a college youth whose
first name was Sidney, and a man who had no
small change.
The conductor is going his merry rounds,
with a volley of "move up front," interspered
with "Fares please."
The tragic moment draws on apace.
The conductor approaches the aforesaid
changeless man.
The man draws a tenner, and says that is the
smallest he has.
A kid yells for a transfer; a stout lady demands that the car be stopped at once; a bald
gentleman falls over a hamper of newly washed
clothes in the care of an old negress.
The conductor glares wildly around, and
when his frenzied glance falls on the x note,
he gives a war-hoop.
It is the straw-hat that shatters the vertebral
column of the proverbial camel.
But see, a fair knight conies to the rescue!
Like Sir Philip Sidney of old, who threw a
cup of water in a dying soldier's eye, this his
modern namesake is all courtesy and grace.
He approches the changeless man.
The latter prudently put away his tenner.
But that is not the purpose of Sidney on
this occasion.
With southern polish, Sid draws a nickel
from his very own trouser's pocket, and relieves the stranger's difficulty.
At once the latter is all gratitude and
indebtedness.
"What is your name, fair sir, that I may
requite you this most opportune loan in a very
short qnickness ?"
"Oh! don't mention it. I always like to
give away a small coin in this manner. It is
only an eccentricity; think of it no more."
"Nay, but you will do me yet greater
courtesy and kindness, if you will but let me
know who has been my benefactor."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
"Truly, sir, I wish no thanks for this simple
deed."
"But let me only know your name, that in
days to come I may ponder, over it as a
synonym for all that distinguishes the gentleman; that it may stand out in my memory as
apart from all other names; that I may transmit it to my descendants as a word forever to
be held in all honor and reverence. For these
reasons, fair youth, impart to me the family
title by which you are known."
"Sir, my name is
Smith."
Stranger croaks.
